comments.body: Course materials are generally not suitable for registration. Instead, the students can `Pkg.add` the package directly from the GitHub URL.

I understand why it wouldn't be a good idea for a single course, and we have functioned this way (via `Pkg.add`) for the last few years. However, this is not for a single course, but for broader discipline-level instruction (i.e., general university-level instruction in this topic). Does the rule still apply?

> Does the rule still apply?

I think so! With educational materials like this, I would point out two things:

1. These types of packages typically are not intended as dependencies for other packages in General. Being a dependency of another registered package is really the only situation where registration is _required_. If the package is intended only for "project environments" (homeworks, labs, etc.) `] add https://github.com/UCLAMAEThreads/FluidDynTools.jl` isn't any more difficult than `] add FluidDynTools` for the students. If the package might also be a dependency in a non-registered package (students developing packages as part of a course), that's still what the [guidelines](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General?tab=readme-ov-file#should-i-register-my-package-now) would consider "only useful for a closed group". For that, it's better to use a [LocalRegistry](https://github.com/GunnarFarneback/LocalRegistry.jl) or the [`[sources]` section](https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/toml-files/#The-%5Bsources%5D-section) in Julia 1.11.

2. One particular organization using a relatively general name blocks that name for any other organization. What if another university wants to have their own materials for teaching fluid dynamics? I actually do think that adding the org name as a prefix to the package somewhat gets around this issue. So, if you wanted to rename this to `UCLAFluidDynTools`, I wouldn't have a problem with the registration, personally (even though technically it's still against the guidelines)

All that being said, I have no special authority to veto the registration. If you convince one of the full registry maintainers, they can still merge manually.
